citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A 10year old male Jaguar, Potion, was holding up its right front paw while in a sitting position and exhibited non weight
bearing to partial weight bearing lameness during locomotion. This animal has been diagnosed in the past with a cracked
or fissured footpad on the right front paw. The last visual inspection of this animal by the attending veterinarian was in
October 2024. According to the licensee the jaguar was noticed to be lame approximately four days ago, however there
was no communication with the attending veterinarian (AV) about the lameness prior to this inspection. The licensee
consulted with the AV during the inspection by phone and instructions for care and medications were given by the AV to
the licensee.
Failing to conduct daily observations or maintaining frequent and direct communication with the attending veterinarian
concerning any veterinary issue observed by the licensee may result in animal discomfort or pain and suffering due to an
injury or disease without veterinary consultation or evaluation.
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily observation of all
animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, that daily observation of animals may be accomplished
by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, that a mechanism of direct and frequent
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. This animal must be examined and assessed by a licensed veterinarian.
Correct by 03/17/2025.

In the outdoor dog exercise pens were several deep, dug holes under the dog houses as well as a section of loose, chain
link fencing with exposed sharp, metal points protruding inward along the bottom.
Dogs could possibly become caught or trapped in loose fencing or become injured from sharp, protruding metal ends or
from holes in the ground. All housing facilities and animal areas must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the
animals from injury, contain the animals securely and restrict other animals from entering. A system of timely
identification, facility repair and maintenance must be in place.
Correct by 03/26/2025.

A shelter structure in the warthog enclosure was in disrepair. The corrugated metal siding is separated at one corner
creating a gap with sharp exposed metal edges. Also, the animal has dug an approximately 2-foot-deep hole under the
back side of the shelter exposing the bottom metal edge.
A chain link fence separating the two deer enclosures was in disrepair. There is an approximately 8-foot-wide area along
the bottom of this fence which in bent inward with sharp, metal points and open gaps.
There was a dug hole approximately one foot wide under the cougar den box exposing an approximately 6in X6in metal
wire material with sharp metal points.
Animals could possibly become injured from sharp, protruding wire ends or metal edges. Additionally, fencing in disrepair
and deep holes in the ground may lead to the animal being injured or entrapped. All housing facilities must be structurally
sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. A system of timely
identification, facility repair and maintenance must be in place.
Correct by 03/26/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A 10year old male Jaguar, Potion, was holding up its right front paw while in a sitting position and exhibited non weight 
bearing to partial weight bearing lameness during locomotion. This animal has been diagnosed in the past with a cracked 
or fissured footpad on the right front paw. The last visual inspection of this animal by the attending veterinarian was in 
October 2024. According to the licensee the jaguar was noticed to be lame approximately four days ago, however there 
was no communication with the attending veterinarian (AV) about the lameness prior to this inspection. The licensee 
consulted with the AV during the inspection by phone and instructions for care and medications were given by the AV to 
the licensee. 
Failing to conduct daily observations or maintaining frequent and direct communication with the attending veterinarian 
concerning any veterinary issue observed by the licensee may result in animal discomfort or pain and suffering due to an 
injury or disease without veterinary consultation or evaluation. 
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily observation of all 
animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, that daily observation of animals may be accomplished 
by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, that a mechanism of direct and frequent 
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being 
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. This animal must be examined and assessed by a licensed veterinarian. 
 
Correct by 03/17/2025. 
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
In the outdoor dog exercise pens were several deep, dug holes under the dog houses as well as a section of loose, chain 
link fencing with exposed sharp, metal points protruding inward along the bottom. 
Dogs could possibly become caught or trapped in loose fencing or become injured from sharp, protruding metal ends or 
from holes in the ground. All housing facilities and animal areas must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the 
animals from injury, contain the animals securely and restrict other animals from entering. A system of timely 
identification, facility repair and maintenance must be in place. 
 
Correct by 03/26/2025.

3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
A shelter structure in the warthog enclosure was in disrepair. The corrugated metal siding is separated at one corner 
creating a gap with sharp exposed metal edges. Also, the animal has dug an approximately 2-foot-deep hole under the 
back side of the shelter exposing the bottom metal edge. 
 
A chain link fence separating the two deer enclosures was in disrepair. There is an approximately 8-foot-wide area along 
the bottom of this fence which in bent inward with sharp, metal points and open gaps. 
 
There was a dug hole approximately one foot wide under the cougar den box exposing an approximately 6in X6in metal 
wire material with sharp metal points. 
 
Animals could possibly become injured from sharp, protruding wire ends or metal edges. Additionally, fencing in disrepair 
and deep holes in the ground may lead to the animal being injured or entrapped. All housing facilities must be structurally 
sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. A system of timely 
identification, facility repair and maintenance must be in place. 
 
Correct by 03/26/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

species.common: BARN OWL / WESTERN BARN OWL / AMERICAN BARN OWL /
